Blocks.heading: Invest in Corporate Bonds
Blocks.subHeading: Expert Guidance Based on Solid Research, Safety Ratings, and Stability

tabs.panelDescription: Invest in high-yield AAA corporate bonds for fixed periodic interest payments and returns up to 12% per year.
Our comparison tool lets you easily see how different bonds stack up against each other, so you can make an informed decision.
From research to advice to execution, we handle every step of the investment process for you. No need to go to multiple sources for guidance.
Our team of advisors is always available to help you navigate the investment process and make smart decisions.

Blocks.subheading: Steps to buy or invest bonds online

items.cardDescription: Explore different bond options, compare yields and terms, and choose by considering your investment goals and risk tolerance.

items.cardHeading: Consultative Call with Fixed Income Specialist
items.cardDescription: Consultative call with a fixed income specialist to discuss your bond selection and any questions or concerns you may have.
Complete the necessary Know Your Customer (KYC) and documentation requirements. This may include providing proof of identity and other personal information.
Confirm the details of the bond purchase with the bond issuer or broker, and finalize the deal.
Make payment for the bonds and complete the settlement process.
Keep track of your bond holdings and monitor their performance over time.

disclosure.disclosureHeading: Is having a Demat account compulsory for investing in bonds through stock exchanges?
disclosure.disclosureDescription: Yes, having demat account is compulsory for investing in bonds through stock exchanges.

disclosure.disclosureHeading: What are the different Modes of issuance of bonds?
disclosure.disclosureDescription:
Bonds can be issued through a public issue or private placement. 
Private placement means an offer or invitation to subscribe or issue of securities, by a company, to a select group of persons (cannot exceed 200, in terms of Companies Act, 2013 and rules issued thereunder), in addition to the Qualified Institutional Buyers. 

Public issue means an offer or invitation by an issuer to the public at large to subscribe to its securities.

disclosure.disclosureHeading: What are various risks associated with investing in bonds?
disclosure.disclosureDescription:
The major risks that can affect your bond’s return are: 

a. Inflation risk: This arises when the rate of inflation increases. This will erode the value of your investment as the purchasing power of the bonds' coupons/ yield and principal falls. 

b. Interest rate risk: Bond prices are inversely affected by interest rate movements. A rise in interest rates could see a fall in bond prices. If interest rates fall, buyers pay a higher price to receive a coupon that is higher than the prevailing market rates. 

C. Call risk: Some bonds have a callable feature which gives the issuer an option to buy back (redeem) the bond before its maturity date at a predefined date. If a bond is called when prevailing interest rates are lower than at the time you bought it, you will be exposed to reinvestment risks.
 
D. Credit risk: Bonds are forms of debt, so bond prices will be affected by the perceived credit quality or probability of default of the bond issuer. When an issuer defaults, you may lose all or a substantial part of your investment. 
E. Liquidity risk: Bonds are usually less liquid than equity. This may happen if the investors of a particular bond issue are largely buying to hold, so there are fewer buyers and sellers. This may make it harder to buy or sell the bonds. Even in cases where the bonds are listed or traded on an exchange, there is no certainty that a liquid secondary market will develop.

 F. Market risk: A bond's price/ value will fluctuate with changing market conditions, including the forces of supply and demand and interest rate changes.

G. Reinvestment risk: In an environment of declining interest rates, investors may have to reinvest the income received and any return of principal at lower prevailing rates.

A. Yield to Maturity: The rate of return that an investor would earn if an investor buys the bond at its current market price & held it until maturity, Represents the discount rate which equates the discounted value of a bond’s future cash flows to its current market price. This is the most scientific tool used while valuing the bond securities.
 
B. Yield to Call: The rate of return an investor would earn if an investor buys a callable bond at its current market price & hold it until the call date.
 
C. Yield to Put: The rate of return an investor would earn if an investor buys a puttable bond at its current market price & hold it until the put date.
 
D. Current Yield: It is calculated as annual Coupon divided by the market Price of the Bond.

disclosure.disclosureHeading: What is the difference between coupon and yield?
disclosure.disclosureDescription: Coupon is the interest received by the bond holder till maturity. Yield is the return received by the bond holder from his date of investment at the then prevailing market price of the bond. On the date of allotment when the price of the bond is at par the coupon and yield of a bond is the same. The yield may be different once the bond price changes based on demand and supply.

disclosure.disclosureHeading: What is meant by clean price and dirty price in bonds?
disclosure.disclosureDescription:
A. Dirty Price: If the bond is traded between two coupon dates, the buyer of the bond will have to compensate the seller for that part of the period between coupons for which the seller owned the bond. The price arrived at after adjusting this factor (accrued interest) is called the Dirty Price. 

B. Clean Price: The price arrived at without adjusting the accrued interest component is called Clean Price.
